title: PM Update: A shower or a storm possible into evening, and it’s another warm one Sunday
text:
Joggers on the National Mall at sunset. (Beau Finley/Flickr)

Clouds were stubborn this morning into the midday, but once the sun broke out it was feeling like summer, especially given the high humidity. Afternoon temperatures mainly reached the 80s, which is still well above normal for the date. A weak cold front passes tonight, but it’ll stay warm and humid into Sunday.

Listen to our daily D.C. forecasts: Apple Podcasts | Amazon Echo | More options

Through Tonight: We run the risk of a few showers or storms into the evening and through about midnight, but most spots should stay dry. Otherwise, partly cloudy conditions rule. Lows are mainly in the upper 60s to lower 70s. Winds turn to come from the north around 5 mph late.

View the current weather at The Washington Post.

Tomorrow (Sunday): Behind a weak front, we’re looking at a more pleasant day than today. That said, humidity is still on the moderate to high side so it won’t exactly be comfortable. Highs range from near 80 to the mid-80s. Winds are out of the northeast around 5 mph.

See my forecast through the beginning of next week. And if you haven’t already, join us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and Instagram. For related traffic news, check out Gridlock.

Snow! The big early-season snowstorm in Montana and surrounding mountainous areas is underway.

First light update from Cut Bank, MT. Snow continues to fall and blow. Penguins have their hats on. Time to rest for a bit. #mtwx #snow #winterstorm @MyRadarWX pic.twitter.com/OwCFNqxMS0 — Aaron Jayjack (@aaronjayjack) September 28, 2019

Current road conditions on Macdonald Pass outside Helena. Watch you speed and remember distance between you and the car ahead of you is your friend. #mtwx #snow #RoadSafety pic.twitter.com/4FLBajXa5p — Trooper Amanda Villa (@TrooperAVilla) September 28, 2019

Just under 15cm of #snow so far in #Kananaskis valley and the wind has been blowing, up to 40km gusts #ShareYourWeather #abstorm pic.twitter.com/MMAtgbvfH2 — Tom Graham (@Washed_Up) September 28, 2019

They’re still expecting up to four feet in parts of the region!
